Award.AbstractNarration:
Oil refineries use heat exchangers extensively for multiple purposes, which include heating and cooling of the reactors and production containers, intermediate products (fractional distillation), as well as condensation of various solvents. Other process industries (e.g., food processing) also have similar needs for heating and cooling, thus resulting in extensive use of different types of heat exchangers. Over time, the widespread use of the heat exchangers leads to their decline in their performance due to fouling and corrosion, as well as due to the inability to provide for their constant cooling. There is a lack of immediate solution to prevent these existing issues in the refineries, due to high operating and capital costs associated with the petrochemical and other process industries. Nanofluids Technology is a promising solution to combat these challenges by improving the energy efficiency (through enhancement of the material properties of the coolants) as well as mitigating issues due to fouling and corrosion. The proposed tasks in the I-Corps project will enable the market survey and identification of bottlenecks in these industries ? thus accelerating the anticipated development of this technology and by enabling more effective insertion and deployment of the Nanofluids Technology based on customer needs.

Nanofluids are capable of altering the thermo-fluidic properties of heat transfer fluids to facilitate better thermal management. This has applications in various industries, including: power generation, transportation (automotive, aerospace, etc.), chemical and food processing, life sciences (e.g., rapid thermal cycling for nucleic acid analyses), buildings, defense and homeland security, oil and gas exploration. The I-Corps team will perform market surveys in the petro-chemical industry for targeted deployment of Nanofluids Technology with the goal of improving the performance of heat exchangers. The I-Corps team will identify the deficient aspects of Nanofluids Technology that need to be improved to be more responsive to the market needs and will leverage the inherent benefits of this technology. The Nanofluids Technology will be demonstrated for various types of heat exchangers to convince the potential customers of its efficacy. This technical demonstration will strengthen the technology requirements and will be guided by target metrics derived from the customer surveys. Techno-economic feasibility analyses of Nanofluids Technology will be performed with the intent of establishing new ventures.

The PI (Dr. Banerjee) along with the 2 students of Mechanical Engineering who served as Entrepreneurial Lead (EL) and the Industry Mentor (IM) at Texas A&M University participated in this project sponsored by the NSF Innovation-Corps program. By conducting over a hundred customer discovery interviews, a strong product-market fit was found for Nanofluid Technology in oil refineries. A contemporary issue (“pain point”) for customers was immediately apparent in the oil refineries, which is: unpredictable fouling and corrosion of the heat exchangers that cannot be prevented or mitigated satisfactorily by the current conventional commercial products/ solutions.

 

Oil refineries use heat exchangers extensively for multiple purposes, including heat recovery within the petrochemical processes, hydrocarbon heat recovery, cooling of the reactors and production containers, cooling and heating of intermediate products, as well as cooling of water circuits and condensation of various solvents. The widespread use of heat exchangers requires their constant cooling, that is dissipation of high amounts of heat flux. The performance degrades over time due to fouling and corrosion.

 

The “Nanofluids Technology” was developed in the PI’s research group with the prime focus on improvement of the heat exchanger performance, which in turn can enhance heat transfer (power rating and energy storage capacity) while reducing corrosion and pumping costs. This unconventional behavior of nanofluids provides excellent value propositions that can reduce both operating costs and capital costs by ~75%. The downstream leg of petrochemical industry is best suited as the target industry for the Nanofluids Technology application.

 

The full impact of this problem was understood through interviews and discussions with employees in the oil-refineries. Positions interviewed include: process engineers, maintenance engineers, inspection engineers, safety engineers and their supervisors and subject matter experts as well as financial personnel. From these hypothesis validation and data collection efforts, the I-Corps team realized that our Nanofluids Technology can be used as an additive to reduce loss due to fouling in the heat exchangers at a 2 to 1 pay-back ratio with a Return-On-Investments(ROI) in 6 months. Additives currently on the market can help reduce fouling, however it was repeatedly mentioned by plant employees that there is not an additive on the market that can reduce fouling to the extent that they desire. Nanofluids Technology can be utilized to coat heat exchanger surfaces with nanoparticles through controlled precipitation from a colloidal solution. Cheap precursors can be leveraged to form nanoparticles in-situ (which then eventually precipitate on the pipes/ conduit-walls). The precipitated nanoparticles form “nanofins” and enable reduction in fouling and corrosion while enhancing the rate of heat transfer for heat exchanging fluids (i.e., improve the power rating and energy storage capacity for the heat exchangers). These heat exchangers therefore operate as a “thermal battery” or as a readily available source of heat energy.

 

This cutting edge invention for preventing fouling was recently discovered for mass-production and published by the US Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO): D. Banerjee, et al., US Patent Application Publication:     20160318067 A1: “Systems and Methods for In-Situ Formation of Nanoparticles and Nanofins”, Publication Date: November 3, 2016). This method allows for rapid scaling up a cheap manufacturing platform for nanoparticles-precursors as additives for process industry applications.

 

The Market Opportunity

Nanofluid Technology has potential for insertion in multiple markets:

  1. Consumer Appliances:
  2. Electronic Chip Cooling:
  3. Bio-technology, Homeland/Bio-Security:
  4. Deep drilling for oil and gas exploration:
  5. Energy Efficiency/ Sustainability:

 

Value Proposition:

(1) Nanofluids Technology can help with decreasing fouling with the aim of increasing the reliability of the equipment while decreasing the overall operational costs (and can be retrofitted into existing systems with minimal impact on the fixed costs).

(2) Nanofluids Technology can increase the life of these heat exchangers and increase their heat transfer in a cost effective way which can enable oil refinery operators (process engineers and maintenance group leads) to improve their margins by saving costs and extending the operational life of heat exchangers, particularly, the pre-heat train heat exchangers.
